absolute refractory period: the time during which another action potential is impossible.
action potential: electrical impulses that travel down the axon and allow neurons to communicate.
anterograde amnesia: inability to encode new memories from our experiences.
aphasia: An acquired language impairment that results from brain damage, typically in the left hemisphere. *See also: Broca's Aphasia, Wernicke's Aphasia.*
chunking: organising information into meaningful groupings, allowing us to extend the span of short-term memory.
cohort effects: effects observed in a sample of participants that result from individuals in the sample growing up at the same time.
corpus callosum: a large band of fibres connecting the two cerebral hemispheres of the brain.
crystallised intelligence: accumulated knowledge of the world acquired over time.
delirium: rapid-onset reduced clarity of consciousness and cognition, with confusion, disorientation, and deficits in memory and language (Barlow et al., 2017).
emic: the approach of studying a culture's behaviour from the perspective of an insider
emotion: pattern of action elicited by an external event and a feeling state, accompanied by a characteristic physiological response (Barlow et al., 2017).
encoding specificity: phenomenon where information is more easily recalled when the conditions under which the information was encoded are similar to the conditions under which we attempt to retrieve it.
erikson: (1902-1994) Responsible for developing the eight Stages of Psychosocial Development theory.*See also: Psychosocial Development Theory.
false negative: assessment error in which no pathology is noted (that is, test results are negative) when one is actually present (Barlow et al., 2017). *See also: Type 2 Error.*
false positive: assessment error in which pathology is reported (that is, test results are positive) when none is actually present (Barlow et al., 2017). *See also: Type 1 Error.*
gene: long deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) molecules, the basic physical units of heredity that appear as locations on chromosomes. A single gene is a subunit of DNA that determines inherited traits in living things (Barlow et al., 2017).
human genome project: ongoing scientific attempt to develop a comprehensive map of all human genes (Barlow et al., 2017).
id: the unconscious psychical entity present at birth representing basic sexual and aggressive drives. (Barlow et al., 2017). *See also: Psychoanalytic Theory.*
job analysis: the process of gathering detailed information about the main tasks and contextual responsibilities for a particular job (Schum et al., 2017).
kleptomania: recurrent failure to resist urges to steal things not needed for personal use or their monetary value (Barlow et al., 2017).
longitudinal design: systematic study of changes in the same individual or group examined over time (Barlow et al., 2017).
mental status exam: relatively brief preliminary test of a client's judgement, orientation to time and place, and emotional and mental state; typically conducted during an initial interview (Barlow et al., 2017).
neurotransmitter: chemicals that cross the **synaptic cleft** between nerve cells to transmit impulses from one **neuron** to the next. Their relative excess or deficiency is involved in several psychological disorders (Barlow et al., 2017).
obsessions: recurrent intrusive thoughts or impulses the client seeks to suppress or neutralise while recognising they are not imposed by outside forces (Barlow et al., 2017).
paraphilia: sexual disorder and deviations in which sexual arousal occurs almost exclusively in the context of inappropriate objects or individuals (Barlow et al., 2017).
stress: the physiological response of the body to a **stressor** (Barlow et al., 2017).
stressor: any event or change that requires adaptation (Barlow et al., 2017).
unconscious: part of the psychic makeup that is outside the awareness of the person (Barlow et al., 2017).
variability: degree of change in a phenomenon over time (Barlow et al., 2017).
wernicke-korsakoff syndrom: organic brain syndrome resulting from prolonged heavy alcohol use, involving confusion, unintelligible speech, and loss of motor coordination. It may be caused by a deficiency of thiamine, a vitamin metabolised poorly by heavy drinkers (Barlow et al., 2017).
reference list:
Barlow, D. H., Durand, V. M., & Hofmann, S., G. (2017). *Abnormal Psychology: An integrative approach* (8th ed). Cengage Learning. 
 Schum, D., O'Gorman, J., Creed, P., & Myors, B. (2017). *Psychological testing and Assessment* (3rd ed.). Oxford University Press.
